body:
Wow, this one appears to be the combination of two separate issues:
1. if a macro invocation is allowed to expand to a item/statement (rather than an expression), it is assumed to do so (https://github.com/mozilla/rust/issues/5941)
2. a macro expanding to multiple items is silently truncated at the first one (https://github.com/mozilla/rust/issues/8012)

#5921 means that, in `twice!($b) + 1`, the `twice!($b)` gets treated as a statement/item macro, and then #8012 means that the trailing `+ 1` gets dropped (and so the behaviour is incorrect, _and_ no error is reported).

This can be fixed by forcing the `twice!($b)` to be evaluated in an expression context (that is what is happening with the `1 + twice!($b)` form), which can be done with some parens:

``` rust
macro_rules! twice_one(
    ($b:expr) => ( (twice!($b) + 1) );
)
```

(Closing as a dup of those two issues.)
